Specific Details: Letter to John McGuinness TD - Wards of Court
Subject Matter: Letter to John McGuinness TD - Wards of Court
Intended Results: As the outgoing Chairperson of the PAC, Inclusion Ireland asked John McGuinness TD to highlight the case of a concerned family member concerning Ward of Court funds to the Minister for Justice or the Minister for Finance for their urgent consideration. We also asked John McGuinness TD to highlight the wider Ward of Court issues contained in the Public Accounts Committee (PAC) recommendations from July 2015 with the Minister for Justice or the Minister for Finance.

Specific Details: DDCI spoke before the Public Accounts Committee to express concerns	 about gaps in Ireland’s corporate taxation and incentives system, along with its	 transfer-pricing  regime,  which facilitate multinational corporations to operate aggressive  tax dodging schemes from Ireland that reduce	their global liabilities and deny	much-needed tax	revenues to low-income countries.
DPOs Lobbied: John Deasy|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Robert Dowds|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Áine Collins|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Paul Connaughton Jr.|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::John Perry|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::John McGuinness|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Joe Costello|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: DDCI spoke before the Public Accounts Committee to express concerns	 about gaps in Ireland’s corporate taxation and incentives system, along with its	 transfer-pricing  regime,  which facilitate multinational corporations to operate aggressive  tax dodging schemes from Ireland that reduce	their global liabilities and deny	much-needed tax	revenues to low-income countries.
Intended Results: Public  Accounts Committee should carry out  a full review	 of  the use of Irish tax	rulings by multinational corporations. We believe tax rulings (1) should not  be open-ended, (2) should	be costed, and (3)	 these costs should be included in government estimates.	Revenue	foregone through	 tax	rulings should be	included	 as	expenditure in the government  estimates and budget.
Lobbying Activities:
We submitted a copy of our report, 'Corporate Tax Secrecy and the State: the Apple case in Ireland' http://www.debtireland.org/download/pdf/20151023141734.pdf

We also submitted an opening statement to the Public Accounts Committee: 
http://www.oireachtas.ie/parliament/media/committees/pac/correspondence/2016-meeting1792101/PAC-R-2077-Correspondence-3C.1---Opening-Statement-from-Debt--Development-Coalition.pdf|Submission|1::DDCI's Director, the Chairperson of our board and the report author of our paper 'Corporate Tax Secrecy and the State: the Apple Case in Ireland' appeared before the Public Accounts Committee on the 21st January 2016.|Meeting|1

Specific Details: Business priorities for Committee on Finance, Public Expenditure and Reform and Taoiseach
Subject Matter: Business priorities for Committee on Finance, Public Expenditure and Reform and Taoiseach
Intended Results: Government must ensure the interests of Ireland and our business community are protected during Brexit negotiations.::Changes to the Fiscal Compact at a European level are needed in order to facilitate increased investment spending.::Revised personal taxation policy.::Changes in taxation to encourage more people to go into business for themselves.::Introduction of more competition in the business funding sector.::Increased spend must be based on a clear economic rationale such as increasing underfunded capital or R&D investment or subsidising activities which are complimentary to a properly functioning labour market such as housing, childcare or education.::Government should work towards completion of the single market and a reduction in red tape including removal of barriers at a national level.::Given Ireland’s dependence on international trade, Government should continue to collaborate with peers in international forums as well as bilaterally with other states to ensure that international policies will enable the Irish economy to thrive.::Ibec supports the development of a new five-year plan to transform public services based on the use of shared services, outsourcing, better public procurement and e-government.::A globally competitive digital economy that delivers jobs, growth and prosperity in Ireland can be achieved through ambitious policy makers and structure. In line with this vision, Ireland should work towards the completion of the Digital Single Market (DSM) with our EU partners.

Specific Details: Tobacco excise
DPOs Lobbied: Enda Kenny|Taoiseach|Department of the Taoiseach::Michael Noonan|Minister|Department of Finance::John McGuinness|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Tobacco excise
Intended Results: Present PJC pre-budget 2017 submission, in which the Company calls on Government to introduce a predictable and sustainable excise plan that minimizes shocks to the legitimate market and stops the illegal trade of tobacco products from growing even further. The plan should be based on objective economic indicators such as average household income, inflation, market decline and price differentials compared to other EU Member States.::The submission also explained how holding the current policy of repeated excise hikes is not the solution to achieve Government’s objectives in terms of revenues and public health.::The submission was also aimed at offering P.J. Carroll's technical expertise to design the plan, but also to study solutions aimed at better tackling the illicit trade of tobacco products, including the implementation of articles 15 and 16 of the revised Tobacco Products Directive (Track & Trace).
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Simon Carroll - Country Manager, PJ Carroll & Co.

Specific Details: To have the cost of business insurance and insurance claims reduced.
Subject Matter: To have the cost of business insurance and insurance claims reduced.
Intended Results: Give enhanced powers to PIAB to determine liability on all claims with very limited exceptions; Review the Book of Quantum with a view to bringing it into line with European norms; An appeal from the PIAB to Court should be on a point of law only; There should be no legal fees for either side at PIAB; There should be enhanced penalties for people found guilty of bringing fraudulent claims; The time under which an EL/PL claim is brought be reduced to 12mths, company to be notified within 30 days.
Lobbying Activities: Emailed with data on Insurance costs following meeting at an event.|Event / Reception|1

Specific Details: Connection to the public sewerage connection via Irish Water.
Subject Matter: Connection to the public sewerage connection via Irish Water.
Intended Results: Information to assist Oaklee Housing on potential costings.
Lobbying Activities: Email sent to Deputy McGuinness concerned Oaklee Housing examining the feasibility of purchasing a property located at Shellmsrath, Callan Road, Kilkenny for the purpose of providing accommodation for people coming from St. Patrick's Centre on the Kells Road, Kilkenny, and the email further said.   We are currently working through  our costings and we are aware that the current septic tank provision in many of the homes in the area are inadequate and reguire upgrading.  We are aware that efforts have been made to examine the feasibility of a connection to the public sewerage connection via Irish Water.   In the absence of information coming from Irish Water, would you be able to advise if the potential for this connection is likely in the near future else we will include into our costings a full upgrade of the current private section tank.  Any information on this would be most helpful and much appreciated.|Email|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: John Mulhall, Development Office, Oaklee Housing

Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: In 2016 the Carlow Chamber met with the TD's representing the Carlow / Kilkenny Constituency to outline some of the priority issues for County Carlow.  The constituency currently has 1 TD from Carlow and it is important to the people of Calrow that all TD's are focused on Carlow.  Areas requiring attention include, commercial rates, local government, funding, subvention, and representation of Carlow.
DPOs Lobbied: John Paul Phelan|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::John McGuinness|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Kathleen Funchion|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Bobby Aylward|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: In 2016 the Carlow Chamber met with the TD's representing the Carlow / Kilkenny Constituency to outline some of the priority issues for County Carlow.  The constituency currently has 1 TD from Carlow and it is important to the people of Calrow that all TD's are focused on Carlow.  Areas requiring attention include, commercial rates, local government, funding, subvention, and representation of Carlow.
Intended Results: TD's were asked in follow up to the previous meetings to outline what they had delivered for Carlow in the past 12 months and what areas of focus they have outlined for the coming 12 months.  It is necessary to know that all TD's in the constituency are focused on the full constituency and not just the immediate parish in which they reside.

Lobbyist Name: Renewable Gas Forum-Irish Green Gas Limited
Specific Details: Requesting Department of Communications, Climate Action & Environment to address as we believe to be inaccuracies, misleading information and mis representations contained in the Renewable Electricity Support Scheme issued for public consultations. As we have reason to believe, is demonstration of further prejudice and discrimination of biogas/biomethane being excluded from technologies listed in the RESS public consultation paper, similar efforts of exclusion in the RHI consultation paper.
DPOs Lobbied: Ross Elwood|Special Advisor|Department of Environment, Climate and Communications::Pat Breen|Minister of State|Department of Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation::Frances Fitzgerald|Minister|Department of Jobs, Enterprise and Innovation::John McGuinness|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Requesting Department of Communications, Climate Action & Environment to address as we believe to be inaccuracies, misleading information and mis representations contained in the Renewable Electricity Support Scheme issued for public consultations. As we have reason to believe, is demonstration of further prejudice and discrimination of biogas/biomethane being excluded from technologies listed in the RESS public consultation paper, similar efforts of exclusion in the RHI consultation paper.
Intended Results: Correct the inaccuracies, misleading information and misrepresentations included in the RESS Public Consultation paper, ensure that biogas/biomethane gets fair and equal treatment as a very viable alternative renewable energy technology with significant benefits available to the wider economy and environmental issues yet to be addressed by Government. The renewable natural gas industry can develop into a significant indigenous industry with added benefits of a circular economy and sustainability
Lobbying Activities: RGFI is endeavoring to inform and ensure that the DCCAE provides accurate, reliable and informed expertise to a critically important industry in Ireland, when issuing topics relating to renewable natural gas for potential inclusion in future policy decisions through public consultation.|Email|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: PJ McCarthy, Chair of Renewable Gas Forum Ireland (RGFI)

Specific Details: Prioritise credit union issues in the Dail. Regulation on levies. Regulation by government that allows delivery of suitable financial vehicle to allow for investment in social housing.
Subject Matter: Prioritise credit union issues in the Dail. Regulation on levies. Regulation by government that allows delivery of suitable financial vehicle to allow for investment in social housing.
Intended Results: Credit unions set out a plan in advance of the last general election with 6 Strategic Steps. These are the steps we want to take, to do more.  Those are investing in social housing, delivering on micro-lending and developing our offering on SMEs.  The other 3 are what we need done, to allow us deliver on our potential.  Better regulation, investment in credit unions and the specific ask that the Oireachtas Finance Committee prioritise Credit Union issues in the Dail (to leverage other issues)
Lobbying Activities: Meeting held in Kilkenny on Wednesday evening 14th March 2018. To discuss our 6 strategic steps and priorities and to allow our local activists hear at first hand from a national politician making their views known in response.|Meeting|1

Specific Details: We met four of the six Oireachtas Members on 14 September 2018 for a Pre-Budget and Trade Union Issues Meeting.Matters discussed included the following: trade union recognition, investment in services, income tax realignment to the benefit of the less well off, VAT rate on the hospitality sector, social welfare rates, housing and health matters, education including restoration of career guidance and pay rates for teachers and in the primary sector we also discussed class size and school funding.
DPOs Lobbied: Bobby Aylward|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Kathleen Funchion|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::John McGuinness|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::John Paul Phelan|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: We met four of the six Oireachtas Members on 14 September 2018 for a Pre-Budget and Trade Union Issues Meeting.Matters discussed included the following: trade union recognition, investment in services, income tax realignment to the benefit of the less well off, VAT rate on the hospitality sector, social welfare rates, housing and health matters, education including restoration of career guidance and pay rates for teachers and in the primary sector we also discussed class size and school funding.
Intended Results: We want to see the policies we raised implemented in the Dail. We want to ensure that we move toward a more equal and balanced society and not the society given to us by successive governments whereby the gap between those who have and those who have not continues to grow.
Lobbying Activities: The meeting took place in the Newpark Hotel in Kilkenny. The cost of the Room, tea and biscuits was paid for by the Kilkenny Council of Trade Unions. While all six Oireachtas members were invited only the four previously mentioned attended the meeting. This is an Annual event for the KCTU as it gives our members an opportunity to voice their opinions and policies on budget and trade union matters.|Meeting|1
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: This was a meeting in which all the delegates of the Kilkenny Council of Trade Unions took part. It would not be accurate to specify any one particular person. The Chairperson of the KCTU is Veronica Drea and the Secretary is Phil Funchion. Nine Trade Unions were represented. These included the following: ASTI, BATU, CONNECT TRADE UNION, CWU, Forsa, INTO,MANDATE, SIPTU and the TUI. The Oireachtas members in attendance were the following: Deputies Aylward, Funchion, McGuinness and Phelan.

Intended Results: Appear at Oireachtas Finance Committee

Specific Details: Pre-Legislative Scrutiny of the General Scheme of the Consumer Protection (Regulation of Retail Credit Firms) Bill.
Subject Matter: Pre-Legislative Scrutiny of the General Scheme of the Consumer Protection (Regulation of Retail Credit Firms) Bill.
Intended Results: To welcome the opportunity to contribute to the legislation.::To highlight that in 2020, new agri-lending accounted for €781 million. Credit outstanding at the end of 2020 is €3.3 billion.  According to the Central Bank, the cost of credit for agri-borrowers is higher than other SME-borrowing  and well above the EU-average. The diminishing level of competition in the lending sector has been  further eroded by NatWest’s recent decision to end its Ulster Bank operations in Ireland.::To acknowledge this Bill and look forward to its implementation. As it stands, Personal Contract Plans (PCPs) are an unregulated form of lending and this legislation will provide greater transparency.::To recommend regular detailed reporting on the lending which is carried out under PCPs. It would be useful if data is collected and made available every six months on the amount and types of these loans.  Specifically, it would be welcome to be able to see which agri sub-sectors (e.g. dairy/beef/sheep/poultry)  are availing of PCP finance. The agri-sector as a whole will benefit from this increased transpareny.

Specific Details: Response from Allianz p.l.c. to the Joint Oireachtas Committee on Finance, Public Expenditure and Reform and Taoiseach in relation to the withdrawal of Ulster Bank and KBC from the Irish Market
Subject Matter: Response from Allianz p.l.c. to the Joint Oireachtas Committee on Finance, Public Expenditure and Reform and Taoiseach in relation to the withdrawal of Ulster Bank and KBC from the Irish Market
Intended Results: Allianz provided the requested information to the Committee in relation to how it was managing its activity in relation to the said banks' withdrawal from the market and how to support its customers affected.
Lobbying Activities:
Correspondence was issued in relation to the Ulster Bank and KBC withdrawal on 3 June 2022 by the Junior Clerk on behalf of Deputy John McGuinness, Cathaoirleach to the Committee, for Allianz p.l.c. CEO's attention, which Allianz p.l.c. acknowledged.

On 15 June 2022, Allianz p.l.c. responded to the Clerk via email with a copy of Allianz p.l.c.'s reply to the request attached.

The letter outlines the issues that have arisen in the context of the withdrawal of the banks from the market, the impact on Allianz p.l.c's customers and how the organization would manage any difficulties that may arise for customers. The letter also outlined the proactive steps Allianz p.l.c. was taking to inform its customers of the need to change their banking details.|Email|2-5

Lobbying Activities:

On 19 August 2022, Allianz p.l.c. responded to the request via email, attaching a letter of correspondence outlining Allianz p.l.c's position on heritage or listed residential buildings and heritage or listed commercial buildings.|Email|2-5
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Sean McGrath CEO of Allianz p.l.c.
